The lack of reducible NiO-interacted species in ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst at reaction temperature (350 °C) renders it inactive towards CO2 conversion. However, the addition of 2.5 wt.% Ce to the catalyst (Ni/Ce-ZrO2) promotes the formation of reducible NiO-interacted species at around 350 °C, resulting in 23–18.5% CO2 conversion, 60% CH4 selectivity, and 40% CO selectivity during 13 h of time on stream. The lanthana-zirconia support features size-optimized stable Ni sites, the highest population of oxygen vacancy/interacted CO2 species and oxide diminution, leading to constant 38–36% CO2 conversion with 100% CH4 selectivity up to 13 h of time on stream through the direct methanation route (without involving the CO intermediate step). In the longer time on stream (11–13 h), the formate species destabilizes over Ni/CeO2 catalyst, CO2 conversion drops (from 33 to 24%), and CO selectivity increases (from 0.5% to 5.3%) at the expense of CH4 selectivity (from 99.5% to 94.7%). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Direct and indirect pathways Lanthana-zirconia Ceria-zirconia Nickel Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Justification The paper entitled “Enhanced direct methanation of CO2 using Ni-based catalysts supported on ZrO2, CeO2-ZrO2, and La2O3-ZrO2: The effect of support material on the reducible NiO-interacted species and catalytic activity” has impressive and directive outcomes for the catalytic community working in CO2 methanation reaction. Simply zirconia-supported Ni (Ni/ZrO2) catalyst is inactive for methanation at 350 °C, but upon the incorporation of 2.5 wt.% CeO2 (Ni/Ce-ZrO2), it becomes active (∼19% CO2 conversion at 11 h time on stream) through indirect routes (through CO intermediate). Interestingly, upon the incorporation of 2.5 wt.% La2O3 over Ni/ZrO2 (Ni/La-ZrO2), the catalyst was performed constantly with ∼37% CO2 conversion up to 13 h through a direct methanation route with 100% CH4 selectivity. CO2 in the gas phase induces a methanation reaction through the indirect pathway (through CO intermediate), whereas moderately/strongly interacted CO2 turns to direct methanation with 100% CH4 selectivity. Activity correlation with relevant characterization has brought deep insight into the catalyst behaviour towards CO2 valorization into CH4. The outcome of the results is informative as well directive for catalytic development for methanation reaction. 1 Introduction Due to its product selectivity toward methanol, methane, and carbon monoxide, the interaction between CO2 and H2 on a supported metal system is a subject of extensive debate. The addition of 10% Zr to the Ti support increased the basicity, enhanced Ni dispersion, and promoted electron transfer from Zr to the Ni valence state, thereby lowering the CO bond dissociation barrier in favor of CO2 methanation [1]. The presence of 3 wt.% ZrO2 along with Al2O3 support was found beneficial as it can firmly hold Ni and inhibit the diffusion of Ni into the Al2O3 matrix or the formation of NiAl2O4 [2]. Thus, the ZrO2-Al2O3-supported Ni catalyst had a high dispersion, reducibility, and chemisorption capacity for nickel. Again, the addition of ZrO2 to a silica-supported Cu catalyst significantly improved CO2/CO hydrogenation[3]. Using ZrO2 as a support appears to be advantageous in terms of CO2 and H2 interaction. In addition, the use of ZrO2 as a support is supported by the anchoring effect of Zr+4 and the possible activation of CO2 at the Ni-Zr boundary [4]. As per the literature report, the reaction routes of CO2 and H2 over ZrO2-supported metal catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . First, it is interesting to note the individual interaction of H2 or CO2 with supported ZrO2. H2 is adsorbed over the ZrO2 surface in homolytic dissociative form (as ZrHZr) and heterolytic dissociated form (as ZrOH and ZrH) below 100 °C [5]. ZnO or CuO-doped ZrO2 had heterolytic dissociated adsorption of hydrogen (as ZrOH) [6]. CO2 is adsorbed over ZrO2 as various types of carbonated species [7,8]. However, if both CO2 and H2 (in a 1:4 ratio) are fed simultaneously, a reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) is very common herein. ZrO2-supported Group 11 metals (Cu, Ag, Au) showed selectivity towards CO and methanol. In-situ diffuse reflectance FTIR studies detected the rapid formation of surface formate species [9]. Formate intermediate of CO2 may be expected to undergo decomposition into CO by reverse water gas shift reaction. Further methanol was formed under the following reaction scheme CO → formadehyde → methoxide → methanol. In this case, Cu and Ag are more selective to methanol, while Au is more selective to CO [9–11]. The reaction route over ZrO2 supported Rh, Pd, Mo or Re catalyst seems to follow both methanol and methane formation routes as it had a mixture of CO, CH3OH and CH4 products. However, CO2 interaction over the “ZrO2 supported Rh catalyst” showed CO-type bond species after CO2 adsorption [12]. The mixture of CO2 and H2 is catalyzed into CO (by RWGS), CH3OH (by hydrogenation of CO), and CH4 (by methanation of CO) over ZrO2 supported Pt or Pd or Rh or Mo or Re catalyst [5,13]. ZrO2-supported Ru catalyst is highly selective to CH4, although Ru is already a good CO hydrogenation catalyst. The formate species are detected in in-situ DRIFTS experiments. It argued the decomposition of formate intermediates into CO (by RWGS reaction) and followed by CO methanation into CH4 [14] over Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst transforms CO2 and H2 into CO-free CH4. It indicated following a different route than the CO intermediate route (indirect pathway) [9]. The eight-electron reduction of CO2 to CH4 by hydrogen needs a much more active catalyst to overcome significant kinetic barriers [15]. The possible route for CO2 methanation over ZrO2-supported Ni-based catalyst without involving CO intermediate (direct pathway) is CO2 → formate → -CH2OH → methyl → CH4 [16]. Gao et al. discussed the role of smaller/dispersed Ni sites, moderate strength basic sites for CO2 interaction and oxygen defect for oxygen mobility towards CO2 methanation reaction [17]. Li et al. summarized the preparation method as well as the nature of active sites, support and promotor toward Ni-based methanation reaction [18]. Ceria is weak basic support as well as offering quick redox property than ZrO2. Ceria-supported Ni catalysts can interact with more CO2 species than other supports. So, among supported Ni catalysts, the activity order of CO2 methanation was found in the following order ceria > alumina > TiO2 > ZrO2 [19]. In an unsupported Ni-Ce catalyst (prepared by citrate sol-gel method), formate species is weakly bonded, resulting in decomposition as CO that does not proceed to CH4 formation [20]. Consequently, the role of support in the reaction mechanism is also crucial. While Ni is the site for H2 dissociation, the presence of ceria and zirconia provides defect-rich mixed oxide, which will serve as sites for CO2 adsorption as carbonate [16,20]. Again, the interaction between hydrogen and carbonate generates formate → -CH3OH species → methyl → methane. Zhang et al. showed that “weakly interacted NiO-surface species” (β-type NiO) is responsible for methanation reaction [21]. Ni supported on quaternary metal oxides system (55% γ-Al2O3 and 15% equivalent of ZrO2, TiO2 and CeO2) had higher surface area, Ni dispersion, lower reduction temperature and higher amount of β-type NiO than individual metal oxide supported Ni catalyst [22]. Therefore, it showed 81.5% CO2 conversion at 300 °C. 5 wt.% Sm-modified Ni-Zr alloy showed higher catalytic activity than the Sm-free catalyst due to stabilizing the tetragonal zirconia phase (by Sm) and enriching the surface Ni atom [23]. At a reaction temperature of 250 °C, it showed >60% CO2 conversion (against 23% CO2 conversion over ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst) and 100% CH4 selectivity. After ceria, lanthana may be an excellent option for CO2 methanation, as lanthana oxide is basic and interacts strongly with CO2. The strong interaction of lanthana with CO2 leads formation of non-reducible/stable carbonate species, which pauses the CO2 methanation further [24]. Previously over SiC-supported Ni catalyst, the promotional addition of lanthana modifies the electron environment surrounding of Ni atoms, restrains the growth of NiO nanoparticles, improves the dispersion of NiO and increases metal-support interaction [25]. Among ceria-promoted alumina-supported Ni and lantana-promoted alumina-supported Ni catalyst, later was found to be better in a mean of stable catalytic performance [26]. At low-temperature, CO2 methanation (350 °C), the catalytic performance of 10 wt.%Ni/La2O3 was minimum among other supported Ni catalysts (as Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Y2O3, Ni/ZrO2, Ni/CeO2, Ni/Sm2O3) [24]. At 20 wt.% Ni loading, CeO2 becomes better support than ZrO2, and Ni/CeO2 shows higher than >95% CH4 selectivity at 350 °C [19]. Upon 15–20 wt.% Ni loading over ZrO2, >97% CH4 selectivity was achieved, and Ni/ZrO2 catalyst seems to be a potent CO2 methanation catalyst [27]. Observing the physio-chemical modification vis-à-vis activity changes will be interesting if ZrO2 support is modified by a small amount (2.5 wt.%) CeO2 or (2.5 wt.%) La2O3 in Ni-based catalyst. Further, the loading amount of Ni is needed to decrease to cut the cost as well as to minimize the chance of bulk NiO formation. Herein, we have prepared 10 wt.%Ni/ZrO2, 10 wt.%Ni/CeO2, 10 wt.%Ni/La2O3 and 10 wt.%Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 (abbreviated as Ni/Ce-ZrO2) and 10 wt.%Ni/La2O3-ZrO2 (abbreviated as Ni/La-ZrO2) catalyst, tested for CO2 valorization into CH4 and characterized with sophisticated techniques like scanning electron microscopy, and Dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental analysis, Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), surface area-porosity analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2-Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO2-Temperature programmed reduction (CO2-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The fine correlation of characterization results with catalytic activity has brought deep insight into the catalyst behaviour towards CO2 valorization into CH4. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Fisher, Germany), Ce(NO3)3.6H2O (Fisher, Germany) and La(NO3)2.6H2O (Fisher, Germany), commercial ZrO2 (Fisher, Germany), Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB; Aldrich), NaOH and Distilled water 2.2 Catalyst preparation The support CeO2 is prepared by precipitation method [28]. 0.1 M aqueous solution of cerium nitrate solution is mixed with 0.05 M CTAB under stirring. 0.3 M NaOH solution is added dropwise for 10 min at room temperature. Then, the pink color solution is centrifuged at 9000 rpm for 15 min, and pellets are collected (by discarding supernatant). It is washed several times (with distilled water), dried and calcined at 600 °C for 2 h. The ZrO2 support is made ready by the calcination of commercial ZrO2 at 900 °C for 5 h. CeO2-supported Ni catalyst or ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst is prepared by wetness impregnation method using Nickel nitrate solution (equivalent of 10 wt.% Ni) over support, drying at 110 °C and calcination under air at 500 °C. The catalyst is abbreviated as Ni/CeO2 and Ni/ZrO2, respectively. Lanthana-Zirconia supported Ni catalyst or ceria-zirconia-supported Ni catalyst is prepared by consecutive impregnation method [29]. Firstly, lanthanum precursor solution (equivalent to 2.5 wt.%) or Ceria precursor solution (equivalent to 2.5 wt.%) is impregnated over ZrO2, dried and calcined. The new support material is abbreviated as La-ZrO2 or Ce-ZrO2, respectively. Furthermore, nickel nitrate solution (equivalent to 10 wt.% Ni) is impregnated over lanthana-zirconia or ceria-zirconia calcined catalyst. The catalyst is abbreviated as Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/Ce-ZrO2, respectively. The scanning electron microscope image and Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental analysis of Ni/CeO2, Ni/Ce-ZrO2, Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/ZrO2 catalyst are shown in Fig. S1. EDX analysis shows the presence of all the claimed elements in the catalyst sample. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The morphology and surface elemental composition of the catalyst sample are analyzed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, model: JEOL JSM-7100 F) furnished with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) and high transmission electron microscope (HTEM-EDX, model: JEM-2100F). The surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of catalyst samples are obtained by NOVA 3200 apparatus (Quantachrome Corporation, Boynton Beach, Florida, USA). Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) method is used to calculate average pore volume and pore diameter, whereas the BET method is used to obtain the surface area of the sample. The adsorption isotherm is plotted between adsorbed N2-quantity vs relative pressure (p/po). The presence of different metal/metal oxide/mixed metal oxide phases is studied by X-ray diffraction (Shimadzu XD-1 diffractometer) facilitated by Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) library database. The XRD instrument has CuKα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) source and Ni filter working at 40 kV and 30 mA. The crystalline size of NiO is calculated by the Scherrer formula about the most intense plane (2, 0, 0) of NiO at 43.25o Brag angle. The reducibility and basicity profile of the catalyst is studied through H2-temperature programmed reduction and CO2-temperature programmed desorption using a Chem BET 3000 (Quantachrome equipment, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. For H2-TPR, the sample is cleaned by heating at 200 °C for 3 h under N2, then cooled to room temperature. Furthermore, the sample is heated to 1000 °C under H2 gas diluted with N2. For CO2-TPD, the catalyst is cleaned by helium for one hour and then after 10% CO2/He mixture (flow rate of 30 ml/min) is allowed to pass over the catalyst at 50 °C for 30 min. Finally, the catalyst was subjected to heat treatment up to 1000 °C (heating ramp 10 °C min−1), and the CO2 desorption signal was recorded by TCD. The valance states extent of interaction, covalency, and oxide enrichment of elements is studied by intensity vs binding energy profile through X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (K-ALPHA, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The instrument has monochromatic X-ray Al Kα radiation source operated from 10 to 1350 eV at 400 μm spot size and 10−9 mbar pressure. The power for the full spectrum pass energy is 200 eV, and at narrow spectrum, 50 eV. 2.4 Catalytic activity test Carbon dioxide methanation reaction is carried out over a 2 g catalyst (diluted with silicon carbide upto 5 cm bed height) packed in a tubular fixed bed quartz silica reactor (length =50 cm, Inner diameter =13 mm, catalyst bed volume 5 cm3) equipped with a programmable electric furnace and K-type thermocouple. The packed catalyst is reduced with 30 ml/min H2 flow for two hours at 600 °C. Then reactor is cooled down, and CO2: H2: Ar (1:4:5 vol. ratio) gas feed is passed over the activated catalyst at GHSV of 6000 ccg−1 h−1, and the catalyst bed temperature is raised to 350 °C. The reactor effluent is analyzed online by a quantitative gas analysis system (Hiden Analytical QGA, England). The mol.% of H2, CO2, CH4, and CO was detected by gas analyzer by using a matrix equation to correct the overlapped detection values from the m/z of 28 (CO), 44 (CO2), 2 (H2), and 16 (CH4). The carbon dioxide conversion ( X C O 2 ), methane selectivity ( S C H 4 ), and carbon monoxide selectivity ( S CO ) are calculated as shown below [2]: (1) X C O 2 = C O 2 , in − C O 2 , out C O 2 , in × 100 (2) S C H 4 = C H 4 , out C H 4 , out + C O out × 100 (3) S CO = C O out C H 4 , out + C O out × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results and discussion The N2 adsorption-desorption profile and surface parameter of the different catalyst systems are shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2. All catalysts have hysteresis loops belonging to type IV isotherms. CeO2 and “CeO2-supported Ni” catalysts have large uptake of N2 at the relative pressure between 0.5 to 0.9, confirming the uniformity of mesopores. Interestingly, upon the incorporation of 10 wt.% Ni in CeO2, the surface area is increased more than 2.5 times (Surface area 83.65 m2/g). It indicates the intake capacity of ceria to expand its framework. In the case of ZrO2 and ZrO2-supported Ni catalysts, such expansions are not noticed, but the surface area, pore volume and pore diameter have decreased upon Ni loading. It indicates the deposition of NiO crystallite inside the pore and at the pore mouth [30]. The hysteresis loop of these catalyst systems is H1, confirming the presence of a cylindrical pore model. “ZrO2-supported Ni” catalyst system has a relatively low surface area (26.17 m2/g), pore volume (0.017 cc/g) and pore diameter (14.36 nm) than the “ceria-supported Ni” catalyst. Over ceria-zirconia or lanthana-zirconia supported Ni catalyst, the surface area drops to about 1/5 times, but pore volume is expanded comparably (than Ni/ZrO2 catalyst). It indicates that the addition of secondary support along with major support zirconia causes contraction in the framework. Ni/ZrO2, Ni/Ce-ZrO2, and Ni/La-ZrO2 have H4 type hysteresis loop confirming the complex type of pore having both micropores and mesopores [31]. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the catalyst system is shown in Fig. 3 (A, B). Ceria-supported Ni has either cubic ceria phase (at 2θ = 28.56°, 32.86°, 47.41°, 56.23°, 69.20°; JCPDS reference number 01-075-0390) or cubic NiO phase (at 2θ = 37.15°, 43.08°, 62.68°; JCPDS reference number 01-073-1523) (Fig. 3A). “Zirconia supported Ni” catalyst, “Ceria-zirconia supported Ni” catalyst and “lantana-zirconia supported Ni” catalyst have cubic NiO phase and monoclinic zirconia phase (at 2θ = 23.96°, 28.10°, 31.37°, 33.96°, 35.20°, 38.52°, 40.62°, 45.02°, 49.29°, 50.09°, 53.86°, 55.23°, 59.90°, 71°, 75.37°; JCPDS reference number 01-074-0815) (Fig. 3B). The crystalline size of NiO about (2,0,0) plane (2θ = 43.25 o) in Ni/ZrO2, Ni/CeO2, Ni/Ce-ZrO2 and Ni/La-ZrO2 catalysts are 26.6 nm, 22.1 nm, 24.6 nm and 13.8 nm respectively (Fig. 2). The H2-temperature programmed reduction and CO2-temperature programmed desorption profile of the catalyst system is shown in Fig. 4 . Generally, ZrO2 is non-reducible, and bulk ceria reduction peaks were reported above 450 °C [32]. Here, the “ceria-supported Ni” catalyst shows three peak maxima at 250 °C, 350 °C and 375 °C. The lower temperature peak is attributed to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen species (on the surface of ceria), the peak at 350 °C is for the reduction of dispersed NiO species, and the peak at 375 °C signifies the reduction of NiO cluster at the interface of ceria. The reduction profile of ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst (centred about 420 °C) belongs to the reduction of strongly interacted NiO species over the ZrO2 surface. It indicates metallic Ni is stabilized over ZrO2 at a higher temperature than CeO2 support. The reduction profile of “ceria-zirconia supported Ni” catalyst is extended from a lower temperature range of 300 °C to a higher temperature range of 430 °C. It confirms the presence of a wide range of reducible NiO-interacted species (having a different extent of interaction with support) over Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst. “Lanthana-zirconia supported Ni” catalyst had more NiO species reduced at a relatively lower temperature than the “ceria-zirconia supported Ni” catalyst. In the mean of CO2-TPD, Ni/ZrO2 has a poor profile (Fig 4B). Incorporating 2.5 wt.% CeO2 along with ZrO2 also does not improve the basicity of Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst significantly. Ni/CeO2 has a CO2-desorption peak of about 138 °C, which is attributed to the interaction of CO2 at weak basic sites or surface hydroxyl [33]. Ni/La-ZrO2 has an intense CO2 desorption peak at the intermediate temperature range (peak maxima about 450 °C) and overlapping peak at strong temperature (peak maxima about 700 °C). The earlier peak is attributed to the interaction of CO2 at medium-strength basic sites or surface oxygen anion, whereas the latter signifies the interaction of CO2 at strong basic sites or lattice oxygen anion. So, it can be said that Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/CeO2 have no basicity, Ni/CeO2 is rich in weak basicity, and Ni/La-ZrO2 is populated with medium strength as well as strong basic sites. The Ni(2p) XPS profile of fresh Ni/La-ZrO2 and fresh Ni/Ce-ZrO2 is shown in Fig. 5 . The peak fit and detail information of each peak like FWHM, peak area and atomic% are shown in Table S3. Ni (2p) XPS spectra of fresh Ni/La-ZrO2 and fresh Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalysts do not show a peak at 852–853 eV, which indicates the absence of metallic Ni. The binding energy at 854–861 eV and 872–879 eV are evident on Ni (2p) XPS spectra for Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 5A). Earlier one is related to Ni (2p3/2) spectral line for NiO, and the latter one is related to Ni (2p1/2) spectral line for NiO [34–36]. It is interesting to note that upon Ce loading in place of La, the binding energy of Ni (2p) electron (in Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst) shifts towards relatively lower binding energy due to donation of electron/charge to Ni or growing negative charge density about Ni (than Ni/La-ZrO2) [37]. Incorporation of higher valent ceria (Ce+4) in place of lower valent La+3 gathers more numbers of O2− than lower valent La3+. So, in Ni (2p) XPS spectra, enrichment of negative charge density may be expected. The O (1 s) XPS profile of Ni/Ce-ZrO2 and Ni/Ce-ZrO2 is shown in Fig. 5(B). For the La-modified zirconia-supported Ni catalyst, the O (1 s) peak is mostly symmetrical, about 531.5 eV, indicating high dopant dispersion. However, for “ceria-zirconia supported Ni” catalyst, the O (1 s) XPS peak of Ni/Ce-ZrO2 is split into three peaks having binding energy at 529.5 eV, 531.5 eV, and 535.5 eV. The peak at 529.5 eV is assigned to lattice oxygen. The peak at 531.5 is due to lattice oxygen that is more covalent in nature, like Ce2O3 [38–40]. The third board peak at a higher binding energy (535.5 eV) may be due to oxygen enrichment [33,41]. So, oxide enrichment upon Ce addition over zirconia-supported Ni is again noticed in O (1 s) XPS spectra. The Zr(3d) XPS profile of Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/Ce-ZrO2 is shown in Fig. 5(C). Ni/Ce-ZrO2 shows a broad Zr (3d) XPS peak, which is extended up to higher bonding energy (than Ni/La-ZrO2). It indicates a relatively higher interaction of support (ZrO2) with dopants in the case of Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst than Ni/La-ZrO2 [33]. To understand the concentration of oxide vacancy, Raman spectra of the spent catalyst system are taken. The Raman peak of fresh and spent Ni/Ce-ZrO2 and Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 5 D–F. The Raman results validate the XRD results also. The catalyst sample has Raman vibration peaks for monoclinic ZrO2 at 178 cm−1, 334 cm−1, 375 cm−1, 470 cm−1 and 625 cm−1 [42]. Ni/Ce-ZrO2 and Ni/La-ZrO2 show additional bands of about 570 cm−1 for the presence of oxygen vacancies [43–45]. After the reaction over the catalyst, the intensity of all Raman bands is decreased (Fig. 5E and F). The fall of intensity is more severe over spent-Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst than spent-Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst. Spent-Ni/CeO2 catalyst shows a single intense peak about 465 cm−1 for symmetrical stretching F2g mode, which is the vibration of 8 oxygen atoms around each ceria cation (or same size cation) [46,47]. On comparing the 570 cm−1 band over the spent catalyst system, it is found that the spent Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst had the highest concentration of oxygen vacancy than the spent Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst and spent Ni/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 5F). The TEM image of Ni/ZrO2, Ni/CeO2, Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/Ce-ZrO2 is shown in Fig. 6 . The Ni particle size over Ni/ZrO2, Ni/CeO2, Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst was found 4.71 nm, 4.67 nm, 4.42 nm and 4.21 nm. It indicates the dispersion extent of the dopant over different support. 3.2 Activity results and discussion The catalytic activity of Ni/La2O3, Ni/ZrO2, Ni/CeO2, Ni/Ce-ZrO2 and Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst in terms of CO2 conversion, product selectivity at 350 °C reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S4. Ni/La-ZrO2 is found to 100% CH4 selective and rest catalysts have major selectivity for CH4 and relatively less selectivity for CO. No catalyst is CH3OH selective. So, these catalysts are CO2 methanation catalysts. “La2O3-supported Ni” is completely inactive toward the CO2 methanation reaction (Fig. S3). In literature, the electron transfer from Zr to Ni was found to lower the CO bond dissociation energy of CO2 [1]. However, in our case, “ZrO2-supported Ni” catalyst is not found much effective in CO2 conversion. The CO2 conversion drops from 25% to 6% within 15 min of reaction time (Fig. 7A). This result indicates that lowering the CO bond dissociation energy is not a single crucial factor for CO2 conversion. Then, what will be a possible cause of the sudden drop in CO2 conversion? Here, Ni/ZrO2 catalyst is reduced at 600 °C before the reaction (reductive pretreatment). After the reduction, the catalyst surface is populated with metallic Ni. The further temperature of the catalyst is put down to 350 °C, and the CO2 and H2 stream is fed together over the catalyst for a methanation reaction. The reaction is initiated by the dissociation of H2 over metallic Ni (which is formed during reductive pretreatment at 600 °C) and, thereby interaction of dissociated hydrogen atoms with CO2. Yamasaki et al. found the CO2 desorption peak from metallic Ni about 410 °C in the CO2-TPD experiment [48]. Kesavan et al. also discussed the oxidation of metallic Ni under the CO2 stream [49]. That means CO2 is oxidizing gas and can potentially oxidize the metallic Ni (which is an active site for the CO2 methanation reaction). In our H2-TPR experiment, it is found that the H2 stream reduces NiO to metallic Ni about 420 °C over Ni/ZrO2. However, the methanation reaction is carried out at about 350 °C. That means if catalytic active metallic Ni is oxidized (into NiO) under the CO2 stream, the H2 stream present over the catalyst is not able to reduce NiO into metallic Ni at 350 °C temperature. The fast loss of a metallic state of Ni causes a sudden drop of H2 dissociation as well as catalytic activity towards the methanation reaction. Overall, Ni/ZrO2 is ineffective towards CO2 methanation. Upon incorporating 2.5 wt.% ceria over zirconia followed by sequential impregnation of 10 wt.% Ni over ceria-zirconia, the surface area of Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst is decreased to 1/5 times, but activity progressed. It has good dispersion of ceria (as no crystalline peak of ceria is observed in XRD) and reducible NiO-interacted species from high temperature (450 °C) to low temperature (300 °C) range. That means well dispersion of 2.5 wt.% ceria over zirconia-supported Ni catalyst induces reducibility of NiO species around the reaction temperature (350 °C). That means if catalytic active metallic Ni is oxidized (into NiO) under the CO2 stream, H2 stream present over the catalyst is able to reduce NiO into metallic Ni at 350 °C temperature. It indicates the stability of catalytic active sites (metallic Ni) over Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst during a methanation reaction. After reduction, metallic Ni becomes sites for H2-dissociation during CO2 methanation reaction. The basicity or CO2-interaction profile of the Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst is very poor. However, the catalyst has good activity towards the methanation reaction. It indicates that for the methanation reaction, both reactants are not needed to be adsorbed on the surface. The dissociated hydrogen atoms over metallic Ni actively interact with CO2 (in the gas phase) and transforms CO2 into CO and CH4. Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst shows an initial 42% CO2 conversion which drops to 23% within 2 h (Fig. 7B). After two hours, the CO2 conversion gets more consistent. The CO2 conversion remains around 23–18.5% up to 13 h time on stream. Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst has higher interaction of dopant with support as well as oxide enrichment than Ni/La-ZrO2. Such surface oxide enrichment over well interacted dopant-support surface seems to guide CO2 methanation through an indirect pathway or CO intermediate route. The CO2 is converted constantly (up to 13 h) into CH4 and CO with 60% and 40% selectivity, respectively (Fig. 7C and D). Previously, Pan et al. prepared ceria-zirconia (Ce0.5Zr0.5O2) support by homogeneous precipitation and observed no CO formation over Ce0.5Zr0.5O2-supported Ni catalyst [16]. It indicates the role of the preparation method is also important in organizing the metal oxide matrix towards CO2 methanation reaction through direct or indirect pathways. Lanthana-zirconia supported Ni catalyst had well dispersed La2O3 (verified by XRD and O(1s) XPS spectra) and reducible NiO-interacted species relatively at a lower temperature than Ni/Ce-ZrO2 (verified by H2-TPR). It indicates the presence of easier reducible NiO over Ni/La-ZrO2 than Ni/Ce-ZrO2. Ni (2P) and O (1s) XPS spectra of Ni/La-ZrO2 show less oxide enrichment than Ni/Ce-ZrO2. Muroyama et al. found that stable carbonates were formed over lanthana-supported Ni catalyst, which could not be converted into successive formate species towards CO2 methanation pathway, and methane was scarcely produced [24]. Previously, the promotional addition of La over SiC-supported Ni catalyst was beneficial towards methanation reaction due to the optimization of Ni size and dispersion [25]. However, in our case, the crystalline size of NiO is found to be minimum (13.8 nm) over Ni/La-ZrO2, which may generate size-optimized metallic Ni sites after reduction. After the methanation reaction, the spent Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst has the highest concentration of oxygen vacancy than the spent Ni/Ce-ZrO2 and spent Ni/CeO2. Oxygen vacancy promotes the adsorption of CO2 onto the catalyst surface [50]. It is again verified by the CO2-TPD profile of Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst where Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst is found to populate with moderately and strongly interacted CO2 species (at medium and strong basic sites of catalyst, respectively). Overall, Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst has sized optimized catalytic active Ni sites, excellent H2-TPR profile and rich CO2-TPD profile. That means the dissociated hydrogen over metallic Ni actively interacts with adsorbed CO2 species and turns into CH4. Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst doesn't show a fall in CO2 conversion from the beginning; the CO2 conversion remains 38–36% from 2 h to 13 h time on stream (Fig. 7B). More importantly, this conversion is 100% selective to CH4 from the beginning of the reaction (Fig. 7C). 100% CH4 selectivity confirms the direct methanation pathway (without including CO intermediate) of CO2 over Ni/La-ZrO2 catalyst. It indicates that the carbonate species formed by the interaction of CO2 over the Ni/La-ZrO2 doesn't remain stable and be converted into formate species which is further engaged to methane formation through -CH2OH to -CH3 intermediates. Ceria-supported Ni catalyst has both cubic ceria and cubic NiO phases, the highest surface area, additional low-temperature reducibility and a wide range of reducible NiO-species (which has a different extent of interaction with support) over the catalyst surface. Yu et al. showed that Ni-CeO2 prepared by the sol-gel method had very weak bonding with formate species, which caused decomposition into CO, and such a surface cannot push CO toward methanation [20]. However, in our case, the Ni-impregnated CeO2 catalyst has as high as ∼50% CO2 conversion, but it attains 99.82% CH4 selectivity after 1 h of reaction (Fig. 7B and C). It indicates that most of the format species (formed by the interaction of CO2 with a catalytic surface) get stable and then mostly move to the direct methanation route. The H2-TPR profile of the catalyst shows an additional peak in the lower temperature range (than other catalysts) due to the reduction of surface adsorbed oxygen. The surface-adsorbed oxygen may play a role in stabilizing format species over the ceria surface. The CO2-TPD profile shows the presence of weakly interacted CO2 species over weak basic sites. However, in a longer time on stream, these weakly interacted CO2 species may not remain stable and affect the conversion. So, during a longer time on stream 6.4 h–9 h, the CO2 conversion drops fast from 48% to 34% without affecting the CH4 selectivity (Fig. 7B). The drop of catalytic activity over Ni/CeO2 catalyst after 11 h is again noticeable. During 11–13 h reaction time, CO2 conversion drops from 33 to 24%, CH4 selectivity drops from 99.5% to 94.7%, and CO selectivity increases from 0.5% to 5.3% (Fig. 7B–D). It indicates that in a longer time on stream (>11 h), format species destabilize and turn into higher CO selectivity. Now, a generalized reaction scheme over Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/CeO2 can be presented (Fig. 8 ). Ni/La-ZrO2 has less oxide enrichment, easier reducible NiO species, and size-optimized stable Ni sites than Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst. Ni/La-ZrO2 has the highest amount of oxide vacancy and the richest CO2 interaction profile among all catalysts. All these surface characteristics over Ni/La-ZrO2 catalysts can guide CO2 hydrogenation towards 100% CH4 selectivity. H2 is dissociated over metallic Ni, whereas CO2 is adsorbed over surface oxide as carbonate over Ni/La-ZrO2 (Fig. 8, Step 1). H2 is dissociated over metallic Ni, which is then transferred to carbonate, and formate is formed (Fig. 8, Step 2). The formate species is stabilized over the surface and moves towards hydroxy methyl intermediate formation in the next reduction step by hydrogenation (Fig. 8, Step 3). In the case of Ni/CeO2, some formate species destabilize and dissociate into CO, which is expelled out (Fig. 8, Step 3′). Further over Ni/La-ZrO2 and Ni/CeO2, hydrogenation of hydroxy methyl is continued, and it turns into methyl intermediate (Fig. 8, Step 4). Lastly, the methyl intermediate is hydrogenated into methane (Fig. 8, Step 4). 4 Conclusion ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst has no reducible NiO-surface interacted species during reaction temperature (350 °C), so methane and CO are produced scarcely over Ni/ZrO2. Upon incorporation of 2.5 wt.% ceria along with Zirconia is found to induce the reducibility of NiO-interacted species (over Ni/Ce-ZrO2 catalyst) in the reaction temperature. After the reduction of NiO at the reaction temperature, metallic Ni becomes the sites for H2-dissociation. The dissociated hydrogen interacts with CO2 (in the gas phase) and shows 23–18.5% CO2 conversion, 60% CH4 selectivity and 40% CO selectivity up to 13 h TOS through the indirect pathway (methanation through CO intermediate). 2.5w% La addition in zirconia-supported Ni (Ni/La-CeO2) catalyst was found to organize size-optimized stable Ni sites, surface oxide's diminution (than Ni/Ce-ZrO2) and the highest population of oxygen vacancy/interacted CO2-species which results into 38–36% CO2 towards methanation with 100% CH4 selectivity up to 13 h time on stream through direct pathways (without involving CO intermediate). Over ceria supported Ni (Ni/CeO2), weakly interacted CO2 species don't form stable format species in the long run. So, CO2 conversion drops (from 33% to 24%), and CO selectivity increases (from 0.5% to 5.3%) on the expanse of CH4 selectivity (from 99.5% to 94.7%) during 11–13 h time on stream. Over the tested catalyst system, it can be said that CO2 in the gas phase pushes methanation through the indirect pathway (through CO intermediate), whereas moderately/strongly interacted CO2 turns to direct methanation with 100% CH4 selectivity. coredata.dc:description: The lack of reducible NiO-interacted species in ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst at reaction temperature (350 °C) renders it inactive towards CO2 conversion. However, the addition of 2.5 wt.% Ce to the catalyst (Ni/Ce-ZrO2) promotes the formation of reducible NiO-interacted species at around 350 °C, resulting in 23–18.5% CO2 conversion, 60% CH4 selectivity, and 40% CO selectivity during 13 h of time on stream. The lanthana-zirconia support features size-optimized stable Ni sites, the highest population of oxygen vacancy/interacted CO2 species and oxide diminution, leading to constant 38–36% CO2 conversion with 100% CH4 selectivity up to 13 h of time on stream through the direct methanation route (without involving the CO intermediate step). In the longer time on stream (11–13 h), the formate species destabilizes over Ni/CeO2 catalyst, CO2 conversion drops (from 33 to 24%), and CO selectivity increases (from 0.5% to 5.3%) at the expense of CH4 selectivity (from 99.5% to 94.7%).

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced direct methanation of CO2 using Ni-based catalysts supported on ZrO2, CeO2-ZrO2, and La2O3-ZrO2: The effect of support material on the reducible NiO-interacted species and catalytic activity
